tit.e: Theory on the Changes of the Dynasties

sen.j: 王朝交替説（おうちょうこうたいせつ）は、日本の古墳時代に天皇家の皇統の断続があり、複数の王朝の交替があったとする学説。
sen.e: The theory of changing hands in the dynasties is a theory in which in the Kofun period in Japan there existed more than one dynasty because of the interruption in the line of the Imperial Family and after one dynasty ceased to exist another dynasty took its place.
Changes of dynasties theories are doctrines which say, due to the interruption in the imperial line of the Imperial Family in the Kofun period in Japan, dynasties were changed several times.
Changes of dynasties theories are doctrines which say, due to the interruption in the imperial line of the Imperial Family in the Kofun period in Japan, dynasties were changed several times.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦前まで支配的であった万世一系という概念に対する批判・懐疑から生まれたもので、昭和27年に水野祐が唱えた三王朝交替説がその最初のものでありかつ代表的なものである。
sen.e: The theory on changes of three dynasties is a theory born out of criticism and doubt against the concept of the unbroken imperial line which was dominant in Japan before the World War II; this theory was advocated by Yu MIZUNO in 1952 for the first time and it is also a representative advocacy.

The changes of dynasties theories were born out of criticism and doubt against the concept of the unbroken imperial line which was dominant in Japan before the World War II, in which a changes of three dynasties theory, advocated by Yu MIZUNO in 1952 for the first time, was representative.

The changes of dynasties theories were born out of criticism and doubt against the concept of the unbroken imperial line which was dominant in Japan before the World War II, in which a changes of three dynasties theory, advocated by Yu MIZUNO in 1952 for the first time, was representative.

sen.j: ただし、それに先立つ昭和23年に江上波夫が発表した騎馬民族征服王朝説も広い意味で王朝交替説であり、崇神天皇を起点とする皇統に着目している点など水野祐の説が江上波夫の説の影響を受けていることを指摘する学者もいる。
sen.e: However, before this theory of changing hands in the dynasties was announced, there already existed a theory which shares the same view in the broader sense; this theory was announced by Namio EGAMI in 1948 and it is called the theory of dynasty established by the conquering equestrian people; in this theory the imperial line is thought to be started from the time of Emperor Sujjn and for this reason there are scholars who point out that the theory advocated by Yu MIZUNO is influenced by the theory advocated by Namio EGAMI.

However, some scholars pointed out that a prior theory of dynasty by the conquering horseback races, which was announced by Namio EGAMI in 1948 and included in the change of dynasties theories in the broad sense, affected the Mizuno's theory since both focused on the imperial line starting from Emperor Sujjn.

However, some scholars pointed out that a prior theory of dynasty by the conquering horseback races, which was announced by Namio EGAMI in 1948 and included in the change of dynasties theories in the broad sense, affected the Mizuno's theory since both focused on the imperial line starting from Emperor Sujjn.

sen.j: のち水野自身、自説をネオ狩猟騎馬民族説と呼んでいる。
sen.e: Later MIZUNO himself called his theory the theory of dynasty established by the neo-hunting equestrian people.
Later Mizuno himself called his as the theory of dynasty established by the neo-hunting horseback races.
Later Mizuno himself called his as the theory of dynasty established by the neo-hunting horseback races.

sen.j: また、古代天皇の非実在論に基づいている点は津田左右吉の影響を受けており、九州国家の王であった仁徳天皇が畿内を征服して王朝を開いたという説は邪馬台国九州説の発展に他ならず、戦前の抑圧された古代史研究から開放された自由な発想により様々な説を自由に組み合わせてできた学説であるといえる。
sen.e: In addition, in certain aspect this theory has influence from Sokichi TSUDA because it is based on the theory of nonexistence of emperor in ancient times in Japan; the theory that Emperor Nintoku conquered provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara and started a dynasty was none other than the development of the Yamatai-Koku kingdom Kyushu theory; in essence it is a theory which combined various theories freely which was impossible before the World War II as study of ancient history was suppressed in those days.

It is said the theory was combined various theories freely by freewheeling thinking released from the studies of ancient history suppressed before the World War II; such as it was influenced by Sokichi TSUDA on the basis of the theory of nonexistence of ancient emperors, and the theory that Emperor Nintoku, the king of Kyushu nation, conquered provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara to start a dynasty was none other than the development of the theory of the Yamatai-Koku Kingdom in Kyushu.

It is said the theory was combined various theories freely by freewheeling thinking released from the studies of ancient history suppressed before the World War II; such as it was influenced by Sokichi TSUDA on the basis of the theory of nonexistence of ancient emperors, and the theory that Emperor Nintoku, the king of Kyushu nation, conquered provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara to start a dynasty was none other than the development of the theory of the Yamatai-Koku Kingdom in Kyushu.

sen.j: 水野の三王朝交替説はその後様々な研究者により補強あるいは批判がなされていくが、現在では万世一系を否定する学者でも水野の唱えるように全く異なる血統による劇的な王権の交替があったと考えるものは多くない。
sen.e: The theory of three dynasties changing hands advocated by MIZUNO has been reinforced or criticized by various researchers; however, at present even among the scholars, who deny the unbroken imperial line, the scholars who think that there was dramatic change of sovereignty with the entirely different blood line are few.

Later, Mizuno's changes of three dynasties theory has been reinforced or criticized by various researchers and at present even among the scholars denying the unbroken imperial line, not many think that there was dramatic change of sovereignty with the entirely different blood line as Mizuno advocated.

Later, Mizuno's changes of three dynasties theory has been reinforced or criticized by various researchers and at present even among the scholars denying the unbroken imperial line, not many think that there was dramatic change of sovereignty with the entirely different blood line as Mizuno advocated.

sen.j: 水野のいう「王朝」の拠点が時代により移動していることも政治の中心地が移動しただけで往々にして見られる例であり、必ずしも劇的な権力の交替とは結びつかないとされている。
sen.e: MIZUNO said that the base of the dynasty changes as times change; however, this point is refuted as change of the political base simply means that the government moved the center of politics and this shift is often seen and it does not necessarily linked with the change in the political power in drastic way.

What Mizuno says the transfer the base of the dynasties according to times is a common example of simply moving the political center, which does not necessarily linked with the drastic change of the political power.

What Mizuno says the transfer the base of the dynasties according to times is a common example of simply moving the political center, which does not necessarily linked with the drastic change of the political power.

sen.j: また、近年では、ある特定の血統が大王（天皇）位を独占的に継承する「王朝」が確立するのは継体・欽明朝以降のことで、それ以前は数代の大王が血縁関係にあっても「王朝」と呼べる形態になっていなかったとする見解が主流になっている。
sen.e: In recent years the mainstream theory is that the dynasty,' in which a specific blood line inherits great king (Emperor) exclusively, did not exist before Keitai dynasty and Kinmey dynasty; advocates of this mainstream theory say that before these dynasties even if several generations of great king shared the same blood line, this political succession was not called 'dynasty.'

In recent years the mainstream is the theory which says that the 'dynasty,' in which a specific blood line inherits great king (emperor) exclusively, established after the dynasties of Emperor Keitai and Emperor Kinmei; until then, even if great kings of several generations shared the same blood line, they were not in a form to be called 'dynasty.'

In recent years the mainstream is the theory which says that the 'dynasty,' in which a specific blood line inherits great king (emperor) exclusively, established after the dynasties of Emperor Keitai and Emperor Kinmei; until then, even if great kings of several generations shared the same blood line, they were not in a form to be called 'dynasty.'

tit.e: 'The Theory on Changes of Three Dynasties' by Yu MIZUNO
Changes of three dynasties theory' by Yu MIZUNO
Changes of three dynasties theory' by Yu MIZUNO

sen.j: 昭和初期（戦前）、津田左右吉は記紀が天皇家の日本統治の正当性を高めるために高度な政治的な理由で編纂されたとの意見を表現し、有罪判決を受けた。
sen.e: In the early Showa era (before the World War II) Sokichi TSUDA found guiltily because of his view in which he expressed that Kojiki and Nihon Shoki ("A Record of Ancient Matters" and "The Chronicles of Japan") were compiled by a highly political reason to raise the legitimacy of the Imperial family, the ruler of Japan.

In the early Showa period (before the World War II) Sokichi TSUDA was convicted for expressing that Kojiki and Nihon Shoki ("A Record of Ancient Matters" and "The Chronicles of Japan") were compiled by a highly political reason to raise the legitimacy of the Imperial family, the ruler of Japan.

In the early Showa period (before the World War II) Sokichi TSUDA was convicted for expressing that Kojiki and Nihon Shoki ("A Record of Ancient Matters" and "The Chronicles of Japan") were compiled by a highly political reason to raise the legitimacy of the Imperial family, the ruler of Japan.

sen.j: しかし、時代はかわり、日本は戦争に敗れ、戦後となると記紀批判が行えるようになった。
sen.e: However, times changed; Japan was defeated in the war and with this change people were able to criticize Kojiki and Nihon Shoki.
However, times changed; Japan was defeated in the war and people were able to criticize Kojiki and Nihon Shoki after the war.
However, times changed; Japan was defeated in the war and people were able to criticize Kojiki and Nihon Shoki after the war.

sen.j: そのような事情のなかで、昭和29年（1954年）、水野祐が『増訂日本古代王朝史論序説』を発表。
sen.e: In such circumstances, Yu MIZUNO published "Zotei Nihon Kodai Ochoshi Ron Josetsu" (Revised Introduction to the Theory on the History of Ancient Dynasties in Japan) in 1954.
In such circumstances, Yu MIZUNO published "Zotei Nihon Kodai Ochoshi Ron Josetsu" (Revised Introduction to the Theory on the History of Ancient Dynasties in Japan) in 1954.
In such circumstances, Yu MIZUNO published "Zotei Nihon Kodai Ochoshi Ron Josetsu" (Revised Introduction to the Theory on the History of Ancient Dynasties in Japan) in 1954.

sen.j: この著書で水野は、古事記の記載（天皇の没した年の干支や天皇の諡など）を分析した結果、崇神から推古に至る天皇がそれぞれ血統の異なる古・中・新の3王朝が交替していたのではないかとする説を立てたが、これは皇統の万世一系という概念を覆す可能性のある繊細かつ大胆な仮説であった。
sen.e: In this book MIZUNO analyzed the Oriental zodiac signs of the years an emperor died and okurina (the honorary name given to an emperor after his death) in Kojiki; as the result he came up with a hypothesis in which he argued that emperors between Emperor Sujin to Emperor Keitei three dynasties of new, middle, and old changed hands respectively; this hypothesis was a delicate yet bold hypothesis which had an possibility of reversing the concept of the unbroken imperial line.

In this book, MIZUNO, by analyzing description of the Kojiki (including the Oriental zodiac signs of the years an emperor died and okurina [the honorary name given to an emperor after his death]), came up with a sensitively exciting hypothesis that three dynasties in different blood lines such as old, middle, and new, were changed from Emperor Sujin to Empress Suiko, which could turn over the concept of the unbroken imperial line.

In this book, MIZUNO, by analyzing description of the Kojiki (including the Oriental zodiac signs of the years an emperor died and okurina [the honorary name given to an emperor after his death]), came up with a sensitively exciting hypothesis that three dynasties in different blood lines such as old, middle, and new, were changed from Emperor Sujin to Empress Suiko, which could turn over the concept of the unbroken imperial line.

sen.j: 水野は、古事記で没した年の干支が記載されている天皇は、神武天皇から推古天皇までの33代の天皇のうち、半数に満たない15代であることに注目し、その他の18代は実在しなかった（創作された架空の天皇である）可能性を指摘した。
sen.e: MIZUNO noticed that in Kojiki the author wrote the Oriental zodiac signs of the year that emperor died only for the 15 generations among the 33 generations from Emperor Jinmu to Empress Suiko; these generations were less than half; accordingly, Mizuon pointed out that there is a possibility that the other 18 generations did not exist (the 18 generations were fictional emperors created by the author).

In the Kojiki, Mizuno focusing on that the Oriental zodiac signs of the year that emperor died were written for 15 emperors, short of half among the 33 emperors from Emperor Jinmu to Empress Suiko, pointed out the 18 rest emperors might not exist (fictional emperors).

In the Kojiki, Mizuno focusing on that the Oriental zodiac signs of the year that emperor died were written for 15 emperors, short of half among the 33 emperors from Emperor Jinmu to Empress Suiko, pointed out the 18 rest emperors might not exist (fictional emperors).

sen.j: そして、15代の天皇を軸とする天皇系譜を新たに作成して考察を展開した。
sen.e: And MIZUNO made a new Imperial lineage centering on the Emperors of 15 generations and developed his discussion from this new lineage.
And he made a new Imperial lineage centering on the emperors of 15 generations and developed his discussion.
And he made a new Imperial lineage centering on the emperors of 15 generations and developed his discussion.

sen.j: 仮説では、記紀の天皇の代数の表記に合わせると、第10代の崇神天皇、第16代の仁徳天皇、第26代の継体天皇を初代とする3王朝の興廃があったとされる。
sen.e: According to MIZUNO's hypothesis, when he matches number of emperors with that of Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, there were rise and fall of three dynasties in which the first emperor was the Emperor Sujin, the 10th emperor, Emperor Nintoku, the 16th Emperor, and Emperor Keitai, the 26th Emperor respectively.

According to the hypothesis, in matching the numbers of the emperors with those in Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, there were rise and fall of three dynasties of which the 10th Emperor Sujin, the 16th Nintoku, and the 26th Keitai were as the first emperor respectively.

According to the hypothesis, in matching the numbers of the emperors with those in Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, there were rise and fall of three dynasties of which the 10th Emperor Sujin, the 16th Nintoku, and the 26th Keitai were as the first emperor respectively.

sen.j: 崇神王朝、仁徳王朝、継体王朝の3王朝が存在し、現天皇家は継体王朝の末裔とされている。
sen.e: There existed three dynasties of Sujin dynasty, Nintoku dynasty, and Keitai dynasty; current Imperial Family is considered to be the descendant of Keitai dynasty.
Three dynasties such as Sujin Dynasty, Nintoku Dynasty, and Keitai Dynasty existed and current Imperial Family is considered to be the descendant of the Keitai Dynasty.
Three dynasties such as Sujin Dynasty, Nintoku Dynasty, and Keitai Dynasty existed and current Imperial Family is considered to be the descendant of the Keitai Dynasty.

sen.j: 水野祐の学説は当時の学界で注目はされたが賛同者は少なかった。
sen.e: In those days there were not many scholars who agreed with MIZUNO's theory although it drew attention among the academic communty.
In those days there were not many scholars who agreed with the theory of Yu MIZUNO although it drew attention among the academic community.
In those days there were not many scholars who agreed with the theory of Yu MIZUNO although it drew attention among the academic community.

sen.j: しかし、その影響は小さくはなかった。
sen.e: However, the influence was not small.
However, the influence was not small.
However, the influence was not small.

sen.j: 水野の学説を批判的に発展させた学説がその後、古代史学の学界で発表されたのである。
sen.e: Later a theory, which developed MIZUNO's theory critically, was brought forth in the academic community of the studies of ancient history.
Later a theory, which developed Mizuno's theory critically, was brought forth in the academic community of the studies of ancient history.
Later a theory, which developed Mizuno's theory critically, was brought forth in the academic community of the studies of ancient history.

sen.j: 井上光貞の著書『日本国家の起源』（1960年、岩波新書）を皮切りに、直木孝次郎、岡田精司、上田正昭など、古代史学のエキスパートによって学説が発表され、王朝交替説は学界で大きくクローズアップされるようになった。
sen.e: These theories included "Nihon Kokka no Kigen" (The Origin of Japan as a Nation) by Mitsusada INOUE (1960, Iwanami Shisho), theories by experts in the field of the ancient history such as Kojiro NAOKI, Seiji OKADA, and Masaaki UEDA; in essence, MIZUNO's theory which advocated the changes of dynasties became the focus of attention.

Starting from "Nihon Kokka no Kigen" (The Origin of Japan as a Nation) by Mitsusada INOUE (1960, Iwanami Shisho), theories were published by experts in the ancient historical science such as Kojiro NAOKI, Seiji OKADA, and Masaaki UEDA then the changes of dynasties theory came to the front in the academic community.

Starting from "Nihon Kokka no Kigen" (The Origin of Japan as a Nation) by Mitsusada INOUE (1960, Iwanami Shisho), theories were published by experts in the ancient historical science such as Kojiro NAOKI, Seiji OKADA, and Masaaki UEDA then the changes of dynasties theory came to the front in the academic community.

sen.j: 古代史の学説を整理した鈴木靖民も王朝交替論は「古代史研究で戦後最大の学説」と著書『古代国家史研究の歩み』で評価している。
sen.e: In his 'Kodai Kokkashi Kenkyu no Ayumi' (The Development in the Studies of the Ancient History) Yasutami SUZUKi, who organized theories concerning the ancient history, valued the theory on the changes of dynasties as the greatest theory after the World War II.

In his 'Kodai Kokkashi Kenkyu no Ayumi' (The Development in the Studies of the Ancient History) Yasutami SUZUKI, who organized theories concerning the ancient history, valued the changes of dynasties theory changes as 'the greatest theory after the World War II in the study of the ancient history.'
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「古代史研究で」を補足し、表記を変えました。
sen.e: In his 'Kodai Kokkashi Kenkyu no Ayumi' (The Development in the Studies of the Ancient History) Yasutami SUZUKI, who organized theories concerning the ancient history, valued the changes of dynasties theory changes as 'the greatest theory after the World War II in the study of the ancient history.'

sen.j: また、王朝交替説に対して全面的に批判を展開した前之園亮一も著書『古代王朝交替説批判』のなかで、万世一系の否定に果たした意義を評価している。
sen.e: Ryoichi MAENOSO, who was critical toward the theory on the changes of dynasties in its entirety, also gave high evaluation to the negation of the unbroken imperial line pointed out by MIZUNO in his book "Kodai Ocho Kotaisetsu Hihan" (Criticism of the Theory on the Changes of Dynasties in the Ancient Times).

Ryoichi MAENOSO, who totally criticized on the changes of dynasties theory, also evaluated the value of negating the unbroken imperial line in his book "Kodai Ocho Kotaisetsu Hihan" (Criticism of the Theory on the Changes of Dynasties in the Ancient Times).

Ryoichi MAENOSO, who totally criticized on the changes of dynasties theory, also evaluated the value of negating the unbroken imperial line in his book "Kodai Ocho Kotaisetsu Hihan" (Criticism of the Theory on the Changes of Dynasties in the Ancient Times).

sen.j: 崇神王朝、仁徳王朝、継体王朝の3王朝が存在した可能性は上記で記したとおりだが、それらについて詳しく述べる。
sen.e: We described the possibility of the existence of the three dynasties of Sujin dynasty, Nintoku dynasty, and Keitai dynasty in the foregoing; now will deal with them in more detail.
The three dynasties of Sujin, Nintoku, and Keitai were possibly existed as previously mentioned, and details are described follows.
The three dynasties of Sujin, Nintoku, and Keitai were possibly existed as previously mentioned, and details are described follows.

sen.j: 崇神王朝は大和の三輪地方（三輪山麓）に本拠をおいたと推測され三輪王朝ともよばれている。
sen.e: Sujin dynasty is supposed have headquarters in Miwa region (the foot of Mt. Miwa) and it is also called Miwa dynasty.
Sujin Dynasty is supposed have headquarters in Miwa region (the foot of Mt. Miwa) in Yamato and it is also called Miwa Dynasty.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「大和の」を補足しました。
sen.e: Sujin Dynasty is supposed have headquarters in Miwa region (the foot of Mt. Miwa) in Yamato and it is also called Miwa Dynasty.

sen.j: 水野祐は古王朝と呼称した。
sen.e: Yu MIZUNO called Sujin dynasty as old dynasty.
Yu MIZUNO called Sujin Dynasty as Old Dynasty.
Yu MIZUNO called Sujin Dynasty as Old Dynasty.

sen.j: この王朝に属する天皇や皇族に「イリヒコ」「イリヒメ」など「イリ」のつく名称をもつ者が多いことから「イリ王朝」とよばれることもある。
sen.e: Among the emperors and loyalty who belong to this dynasty, many people have the name with 'iri' such as 'Irihiko' and 'Irihime'; for this reason, some people call this dynasty as 'Iri dynasty.'
Since many of the emperors and the imperial family belonging to this dynasty have the name with 'iri' such as 'Irihiko' and 'Irihime,' it is also called as 'Iri Dynasty.'
Since many of the emperors and the imperial family belonging to this dynasty have the name with 'iri' such as 'Irihiko' and 'Irihime,' it is also called as 'Iri Dynasty.'

sen.j: この名称はこの時期に限られており、後代に贈られた和風諡号とは考えられない。
sen.e: This name is limited to this time period and it is not regarded as the Japanese- style okurina (the posthumous title given after the death of the person in question).
This name is limited to this period of time and it is not regarded as the Japanese-style okurina (the posthumous title given after the death of the person in question).
This name is limited to this period of time and it is not regarded as the Japanese-style okurina (the posthumous title given after the death of the person in question).

sen.j: 崇神の名はミマキイリヒコイニエ、垂仁の名はイクメイリヒコイサチである。
sen.e: The name of Sujin is Mimaki Irihiko Inie and the name of Suinin is Ikume Irihiko Isachi.
The name of Sujin was Mimaki Irihiko Inie and that of Suinin was Ikume Irihiko Isachi.
The name of Sujin was Mimaki Irihiko Inie and that of Suinin was Ikume Irihiko Isachi.

sen.j: 他にも崇神の子でトヨキイリヒコ・トヨキイリヒメなどがいる。
sen.e: There are also Toyoki Irihiko and Toyoki Irihime and so forth in children of Sujin.
Sujin also had children such as Toyoki Irihiko and Toyoki Irihime.
Sujin also had children such as Toyoki Irihiko and Toyoki Irihime.

sen.j: ただし、崇神・垂仁天皇らの実在性には疑問視する人も多い。
sen.e: However, there are many people who doubt the existence of the Emperor Sujin and the Emperor Suinin.
However, many people doubt the existence of the Emperor Sujin and the Emperor Suinin.
However, many people doubt the existence of the Emperor Sujin and the Emperor Suinin.

sen.j: 古墳の編年などから大型古墳はその時代の盟主（大王）の墳墓である可能性が高いことなどから推測すると、古墳時代の前期（3世紀の中葉から4世紀の初期）に奈良盆地の東南部の三輪山山麓に大和古墳群・柳本大塚が展開し、渋谷向山古墳（景行陵に比定）、箸墓古墳（卑弥呼の墓と推測する研究者もいる）、行燈山古墳（崇神陵に比定）、メスリ山古墳、西殿塚古墳（手白香皇女墓と比定）などの墳丘長が300から200メートルある大古墳が点在し、この地方（現桜井市や天理市）に王権があったことがわかる。
sen.e: From the chronological order of kofun (tumulus) it is very likely that the kofun in the immense size is a tomb of leader of the time (great king); therefore, we can surmise that in the early Kofun period (from about the middle of the third century to the early fourth century) a group of Yamato kofun and Yanagimoto Otsuka Kofun developed at the foot of the Mt. Miwa which was located in the southeast region of Nara basin; these were immense with the length of 300 meters to 200 meters and included kofun built on top of hills such as Shibutani Mukoyama Kofun (identified as a mausoleum of Emperor Keiko), Hashihaka Kofun (surmised by some researchers to be a grave of Himiko), Andonyama Kofun (identified as a mausoleum of Emperor Sujin), Mesuriyama Kofun, Nishitonotsuka Kofun (identified as the grave of Tashiraka no Himemiko); because of this existence of the group of huge kofun, we can understand that there was a sovereignty in this region (present day Sakurai City and Tenri City).

Assuming from the high possibility of large kofun (tumulus) being a tomb of leader (great king) of the time by the chronological order of kofun and others, the following kofun tumulus show there was a sovereignty in this region (present day Sakurai City and Tenri City): Yamato-kofun Tumulus Clusters and Yanagimoto Otsuka Tumulus built at the foot of the Mt. Miwa, in the southeast of Nara basin in the early Kofun period (from about the middle of the third century to the early fourth century), and large scattered kofun with the hill length of 300 meters to 200 meters such as Shibutani Mukoyama-kofun Tumulus (identified as a mausoleum of Emperor Keiko), Hashihaka-kofun Tumulus (surmised by some researchers to be a grave of Himiko), Andonyama-kofun Tumulus (identified as a mausoleum of Emperor Sujin), Mesuriyama-kofun Tumulus, and Nishitonotsuka-kofun Tumulus (identified as the grave of Tashiraka no Himemiko).

Assuming from the high possibility of large kofun (tumulus) being a tomb of leader (great king) of the time by the chronological order of kofun and others, the following kofun tumulus show there was a sovereignty in this region (present day Sakurai City and Tenri City): Yamato-kofun Tumulus Clusters and Yanagimoto Otsuka Tumulus built at the foot of the Mt. Miwa, in the southeast of Nara basin in the early Kofun period (from about the middle of the third century to the early fourth century), and large scattered kofun with the hill length of 300 meters to 200 meters such as Shibutani Mukoyama-kofun Tumulus (identified as a mausoleum of Emperor Keiko), Hashihaka-kofun Tumulus (surmised by some researchers to be a grave of Himiko), Andonyama-kofun Tumulus (identified as a mausoleum of Emperor Sujin), Mesuriyama-kofun Tumulus, and Nishitonotsuka-kofun Tumulus (identified as the grave of Tashiraka no Himemiko).

sen.j: さらに、これらの王たちの宮（都）は『記紀』によれば、先に挙げた大古墳のある地域と重なっていることを考え合わせると、崇神に始まる政権はこの地域を中心に成立した推測でき、三輪政権と呼ぶことができる。
sen.e: Furthermore according to "Kojiki and Nihon Shoki," the capitals of these Kings overlap with a region with kofun; for this reason, we can surmise that the political regime which started with Emperor Suijin was established centering on this region and can be called as the Miwa government, too.

Furthermore according to the "Kojiki" and the "Nihon Shoki," the capitals of these kings overlap with a region with previously-mentioned kofun, the regime started with Emperor Sujin is estimated to have been established centering on this region and can be called as the Miwa Regime.

Furthermore according to the "Kojiki" and the "Nihon Shoki," the capitals of these kings overlap with a region with previously-mentioned kofun, the regime started with Emperor Sujin is estimated to have been established centering on this region and can be called as the Miwa Regime.

sen.j: 日本古代国家の形成という視点から三輪政権は、初期大和政権と捉えることができる。
sen.e: From the viewpoint of the formation of the ancient state of Japan, the Miwa Regime can be thought to be the first Yamato government.
From the viewpoint of the formation of the ancient state of Japan, the Miwa Regime can be thought to be the first Yamato Administration.
From the viewpoint of the formation of the ancient state of Japan, the Miwa Regime can be thought to be the first Yamato Administration.

sen.j: この政権の成立年代は3世紀中葉か末ないし4世紀前半と推測されている。
sen.e: The date this regime formed is thought to be about the middle of the third century or the end of the fourth century.
The date this regime formed is thought to be about the middle of the third century or the end of the fourth century.
The date this regime formed is thought to be about the middle of the third century or the end of the fourth century.

sen.j: それは古墳時代前期に当たり、形式化された巨大古墳が築造された。
sen.e: It is the early Kofun period; during this period formalized giant kofun were built.
That was the early Kofun period when formalized giant kofun were built.
That was the early Kofun period when formalized giant kofun were built.

sen.j: 政権の性格は、「鬼道を事とし、能く衆を惑わす」卑弥呼を女王とする邪馬台国の呪術的政権ではなく、宗教的性格は残しながらもより権力的な政権であったと考えられている。
sen.e: The nature of the regime is not like the regime of Yamatai-Koku in which Queen Himiko was a shaman and 'the art of shaman was regularly used and the people under her regime were confused'; it is thought that the regime is more of the government of power although it retained some religious nature.

The nature of the regime is considered not like that of the magical regime of Yamatai-koku Kingdom with Queen Himiko who 'used the art of shaman and often misled the people,' but more powerful government remaining the religious nature.

The nature of the regime is considered not like that of the magical regime of Yamatai-koku Kingdom with Queen Himiko who 'used the art of shaman and often misled the people,' but more powerful government remaining the religious nature.

sen.j: 応神王朝は天皇の宮と御陵が河内に多いことから河内王朝ともよばれている。
sen.e: Ojin Ocho is also called as Kawachi Ocho because there are many imperial palaces and the mausoleums of Emperors in Kawachi.
Ojin Dynasty was also called as Kawachi Dynasty since many imperial palaces and the mausoleums of the emperors were built in Kawachi area.
Ojin Dynasty was also called as Kawachi Dynasty since many imperial palaces and the mausoleums of the emperors were built in Kawachi area.

sen.j: この王朝に属する天皇や皇族に「ワケ」のつく名称をもつ者が多いことから「ワケ王朝」とよばれることもある。
sen.e: This Ocho is also called 'Wake Ocho' because there are many Emperors and royalty who have the name of 'Wake.'
It was also called 'Wake Dynasty' since many emperors and imperial family belonging with this dynasty had 'wake' in their names.
It was also called 'Wake Dynasty' since many emperors and imperial family belonging with this dynasty had 'wake' in their names.

sen.j: 河内王朝は上記の王朝交替論のなかでも大きな位置を占める。
sen.e: Kawachi dynasty occupies a big position in the theory on the changes of the dynasties.
Kawachi Dynasty occupies a big position in the previous theory on the changes of the dynasties.
Kawachi Dynasty occupies a big position in the previous theory on the changes of the dynasties.

sen.j: その理由は、前後の二つの王朝を結ぶ位置に河内王朝が存在するからである。
sen.e: The reason lies in that Kawachi dynasty exists in the position to connect two dynasties of the one before this dynasty and the one after this dynasty.
The reason lies in that Kawachi Dynasty existed in the position to connect two dynasties of the former and latter.
The reason lies in that Kawachi Dynasty existed in the position to connect two dynasties of the former and latter.

sen.j: 水野祐は中王朝と呼称し、一般に初期大和政権、第2次大和政権などと呼ばれる王朝である。
sen.e: Yu MIZUNO calls this dynasty the Middle dynasty; in general it is called the early Yamato regime, the second Yamato regime and so forth.
Yu MIZUNO called this dynasty the Middle Dynasty which was generally called the first Yamato Administration, the second Yamato Administration and so on.
Yu MIZUNO called this dynasty the Middle Dynasty which was generally called the first Yamato Administration, the second Yamato Administration and so on.

sen.j: なお、応神天皇を架空の天皇とする見解もある。
sen.e: In addition, there is a view which makes the Emperor Ojin be a fictional Emperor.
In addition, there is a view which makes the Emperor Ojin be a fictional Emperor.
In addition, there is a view which makes the Emperor Ojin be a fictional Emperor.

sen.j: 応神天皇の出生が伝説的であることから、応神天皇と仁徳天皇は本来同一の人格であったものが三輪王朝と河内王朝を結びつけるために二つに分離されて応神天皇が作り出されたとする説で、この場合王朝は仁徳王朝とよばれる。
sen.e: This view advocates that Emperor Ojin was created to connect Miwa dynasty and Kawachi dynasty and originally Emperor Ojin and Emperor Nintoku were the same person as the birth of Emperor Ojin is legendary; in this view, this dynasty is called Nintoku dynasty.

In this view advocating that from the legendary birth of Emperor Ojin, Emperor Ojin who was originally the same person as Emperor Nintoku was created dividing from Emperor Nintoku to connect Miwa Dynasty and Kawachi Dynasty, this dynasty is called Nintoku Dynasty.

In this view advocating that from the legendary birth of Emperor Ojin, Emperor Ojin who was originally the same person as Emperor Nintoku was created dividing from Emperor Nintoku to connect Miwa Dynasty and Kawachi Dynasty, this dynasty is called Nintoku Dynasty.

sen.j: 水野祐も仁徳王朝としている。
sen.e: Yu MIZUNO also defines this dynasty as Nintoku dynasty.
Yu MIZUNO also defined this dynasty as Nintoku Dynasty.
Yu MIZUNO also defined this dynasty as Nintoku Dynasty.

sen.j: 河内王朝（応神王朝）は、宋書に倭の五王が10回にわたり遣使したという記事があり、それが傍証となり、倭の五王が河内王朝の大王であったことはほぼ間違いないとされることから、個々の大王に関しての比定は諸説あるとしても、王朝全体の実在の可能性は高い。
sen.e: In Book of Song, a historical text of the Liu Song Dynasty of the Southern Dynasties of China, there is an article which says that five kings of Wa sent envoys 10 times to China; according to the scholars of the ancient history of Japan, it is almost certain that the five kings of Wa were great kings of Kawachi dynasty because the article in the Book of Song can be served as a collateral evidence; the existence of this dynasty in its entirety is very likely although there may be various theories concerning the identification of individual kings.

The collateral evidence of the article in Sosho (the history books of Liu Song Dynasty of the Southern Dynasties of China compiled in 488) that the five kings of Wa (ancient Japan) sent envoys 10 times to Chinashows the five kings of Wa could be little doubt of being great kings of Kawachi Dynasty (Ojin Dynasty), while various theories are concerning the identification of each king, it is very likely that the whole dynasty existed.

The collateral evidence of the article in Sosho (the history books of Liu Song Dynasty of the Southern Dynasties of China compiled in 488) that the five kings of Wa (ancient Japan) sent envoys 10 times to Chinashows the five kings of Wa could be little doubt of being great kings of Kawachi Dynasty (Ojin Dynasty), while various theories are concerning the identification of each king, it is very likely that the whole dynasty existed.

sen.j: また、大阪平野には、河内の古市墳群にある誉田御廟山古墳（応神天皇陵）や和泉の百舌鳥古墳群にある大仙陵古墳（仁徳天皇陵）など巨大な前方後円墳が現存することや、15代応神は難波の大隅宮に、16代仁徳は難波の高津宮に、18代反正は丹比（大阪府松原市）柴垣に、それぞれ大阪平野の河内や和泉に都が設置されていることなどから、河内王朝時代に大阪平野に強大な政治権力の拠点があったことがわる。
sen.e: In addition, in Osaka plain, huge Zenpo Koen Fun (keyhole-shaped mound) such as Konda Gobyoyama kofun in Furuichi Kofun group of Kawachi (the mausoleum of Emperor Ojin), Daisenryo kofun (Nintoku Burial Mound) in Mozu Kofun group in Izumi Province exist and the capital for several Emperors were established in Kawachi or Izumi Province; for example, the 5th Emperor Ojin had his Osumi no Miya in Naniwa; the 16th Emperor Nintoku had Takatsu no Miya in Naniwa; the 18th Emperor Hanzei had his capital in Shibagaki,Tajihi (present day Matsubara City, Osaka Prefecture); the existence of these groups of kofun and capitals show us that a base of powerful political power existed in Osaka plain during the Kawachi dynasty.

In addition, following facts show that a base of the powerful political power was placed in Osaka Plain during Kawachi Dynasty; the current existence of huge keyhole-shaped mounds such as Konda Gobyoyama-kofun Tumulus (the mausoleum of Emperor Ojin) in Furuichi-kofun Tumulus Clusters in Kawachi and Daisenryo-kofun Tumulus (the mausoleum of Emperor Nintoku) in Mozu-kofun Tumulus Clusters in Izumi, and the capitals each established in Kawachi or Izumi in Osaka Plain, such as the Osumi no Miya (Palace) of the 15th Ojin in Naniwa, the Takatsu no Miya of the 16th Nintoku in Naniwa, and the 18th Hanzei in Shibagaki in Tajihi (Matsubara City, Osaka Prefecture).

In addition, following facts show that a base of the powerful political power was placed in Osaka Plain during Kawachi Dynasty; the current existence of huge keyhole-shaped mounds such as Konda Gobyoyama-kofun Tumulus (the mausoleum of Emperor Ojin) in Furuichi-kofun Tumulus Clusters in Kawachi and Daisenryo-kofun Tumulus (the mausoleum of Emperor Nintoku) in Mozu-kofun Tumulus Clusters in Izumi, and the capitals each established in Kawachi or Izumi in Osaka Plain, such as the Osumi no Miya (Palace) of the 15th Ojin in Naniwa, the Takatsu no Miya of the 16th Nintoku in Naniwa, and the 18th Hanzei in Shibagaki in Tajihi (Matsubara City, Osaka Prefecture).

sen.j: 河内に本拠地を置き、河内湾に港を築き、水軍を養い、瀬戸内海の制海権を握っていたことは確かである。
sen.e: It is certain that this government established a base in Kawachi, built a port in Kawachi bay, which existed in those days, maintained the military capable of fighting on the water, and had the controlling power of the Seto Inland Sea.
It is certain that based in Kawachi, it built a port in Kawachi-wan bay, maintained the Suigun Navy, and controlled of the Seto Inland Sea.
It is certain that based in Kawachi, it built a port in Kawachi-wan bay, maintained the Suigun Navy, and controlled of the Seto Inland Sea.

sen.j: また、たびたび宋へ遣使を行い、朝鮮半島への外征も行うなど航海術に関しても優れたものを持ち、アジアへとつながる海洋国家であったことがわかる。
sen.e: This government sent envoys to Song in China and conducted expeditions to Korean Peninsula; from these activities we can see that this government was an excellent maritime state with the art of navigation connected with Asia
This government was a maritime state connecting to Asia having superior seamanship such as sending envoys to Sung Dynasty and sail to Korean Peninsula.
This government was a maritime state connecting to Asia having superior seamanship such as sending envoys to Sung Dynasty and sail to Korean Peninsula.

sen.j: この河内王朝説を批判する論者に門脇禎二がいる。
sen.e: Teiji Kadowaki is one of the disputants who criticize this Kawachi Dynasty Theory.
Teiji KADOWAKI was one of the disputants who criticize this Kawachi Dynasty Theory.
Teiji KADOWAKI was one of the disputants who criticize this Kawachi Dynasty Theory.

sen.j: 門脇は河内平野の開発は新王朝の樹立などではなく、初期大和政権の河内地方への進出であったとする。
sen.e: According to Kadowaki, the development of the Kawachi plain was not the establishment of a new dynasty but the advance made by the early Yamato regime to the Kawachi region.
According to Kadowaki, the development of the Kawachi Plain was not the establishment of a new dynasty but the advance by the first Yamato Administration to the Kawachi region.
According to Kadowaki, the development of the Kawachi Plain was not the establishment of a new dynasty but the advance by the first Yamato Administration to the Kawachi region.

sen.j: また、河内王朝説でも直木孝次郎、岡田精司の瀬戸内海の制海権を握って勢力を強大化させた河内の勢力が初期大和政権と対立し、それを打倒したとする説や上田正昭の三輪王朝（崇神王朝）が滅んで河内王朝（応神王朝）に受け継がれたとする説と、水野、井上の九州の勢力が応神天皇または仁徳天皇の時代に征服者として畿内に侵攻したとする説とがある。
sen.e: In scholars who advocate the Kawachi Dynasty Theory, there are differences of opinion; Kojiro NAOKI and Seiji OKADA think that a group who had the controlling power of the Seto Inland Sea and who made themselves quite strong came into collision with the early Yamato government and overthrew the government; According to Masaaki UEDA, after the fall of the Miwa dynasty (Sujin dynasty), the government was inherited by Kawachi Dynasty (Ojin Dynasty); on the other hand, MIZUNO and INOUE have a theory in which a military power in Kyushu invaded and attacked provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara during the Era of Emperor Ojin or Emperor Nintoku and it conquered the region.

In the Kawachi Dynasty Theory, there are different opinions as follows: One by Kojiro NAOKI and Seiji OKADA that a Kawachi power which controlled the Seto Inland Sea to enlarge its power conflicted and overthrew the first Yamato Administration, another by Masaaki UEDA that after the fall of the Miwa Dynasty (Sujin Dynasty) it was succeeded by Kawachi Dynasty (Ojin Dynasty), and the other by Mizuno and Inoue that a Kyushu power invaded to the area surrounding Kyoto and Nara as conquerors during the reign of Emperor Ojin or Emperor Nintoku.

In the Kawachi Dynasty Theory, there are different opinions as follows: One by Kojiro NAOKI and Seiji OKADA that a Kawachi power which controlled the Seto Inland Sea to enlarge its power conflicted and overthrew the first Yamato Administration, another by Masaaki UEDA that after the fall of the Miwa Dynasty (Sujin Dynasty) it was succeeded by Kawachi Dynasty (Ojin Dynasty), and the other by Mizuno and Inoue that a Kyushu power invaded to the area surrounding Kyoto and Nara as conquerors during the reign of Emperor Ojin or Emperor Nintoku.

sen.j: 継体天皇は応神天皇5代の末裔とされているが、これが事実かどうかは判断がわかれている。
sen.e: The Emperor Keitai is considered to be the fifth descendant of Emperor Ojin, but the opinion is divided whether this is a fact or not.
The Emperor Keitai is considered to be the fifth descendant of Emperor Ojin, but the decision is divided whether this is a fact or not.
The Emperor Keitai is considered to be the fifth descendant of Emperor Ojin, but the decision is divided whether this is a fact or not.

sen.j: 水野祐は継体天皇は近江か越前の豪族であり皇位を簒奪したとした。
sen.e: Yu MIZUNO thinks that Emperor Keitai was from a powerful family based in either Omi Province or Echizen Province and he usurped the throne.
Yu MIZUNO thought that Emperor Keitai who was from a local ruling family in either Omi or Echizen usurped the throne.
Yu MIZUNO thought that Emperor Keitai who was from a local ruling family in either Omi or Echizen usurped the throne.

sen.j: また、即位後もすぐには大和の地にはいらず、北河内や南山城などの地域を転々とし、即位20年目に大和にはいったことから、大和には継体天皇の即位を認めない勢力があって戦闘状態にあったと考える説（直木孝次郎説）や、継体天皇は女系の天皇で、近江の息長氏などは大王家に妃を何度となく入れているが、継体天皇はその大王家の母方といえる息長氏系統の王位継承資格者で、皇位簒奪のような王朝交替はなかったと考える説（平野邦雄説）がある。
sen.e: The Emperor Keitai did not enter the land of Yamato immediately after the enthronement; he kept moving from place to place such as Kitakawachi or Minami Yamashiro and after the 20th year from the enthronement he finally entered Yamato; for this reason, there was a powerful clan which did not recognize the enthronement of Emperor Keitai and there was a state of war (theory advocated by Kojiro NAOKI); the Emperor Keitai was Emperor who was on the side of the maternal line and Okinaga clan in Omi gave his daughters many time to great kings; Emperor Keitai was a qualified person to succeed to Imperial throne who was in line of Okinaga clan; therefore, there was no such a thing as usurpation of imperial throne (A theory advocated by Kunio HIRANO).

Since the Emperor Keitai entered Yamato not immediately after the enthronement but the 20th year later after moving from place to place such as Kitakawachi or Minami-yamashiro, there are two following theories: One that considers due to a power in Yamato which didn't allow the enthronement of Emperor Keitai, the region was in the combat situation (theory by Kojiro NAOKI) and the other that, since Keitai, the emperor of the maternal side, was a successor to the throne in the linage of the Okinaga clan in Omi, which daughters often married those in the great king family, there was no such change of dynasties as usurpation of imperial throne (theory by Kunio HIRANO).

Since the Emperor Keitai entered Yamato not immediately after the enthronement but the 20th year later after moving from place to place such as Kitakawachi or Minami-yamashiro, there are two following theories: One that considers due to a power in Yamato which didn't allow the enthronement of Emperor Keitai, the region was in the combat situation (theory by Kojiro NAOKI) and the other that, since Keitai, the emperor of the maternal side, was a successor to the throne in the linage of the Okinaga clan in Omi, which daughters often married those in the great king family, there was no such change of dynasties as usurpation of imperial throne (theory by Kunio HIRANO).

sen.j: なお、継体天皇が事実応神天皇の5代の末裔であったとしても、ヨーロッパ的な王朝の概念からみればこれは立派な別王朝であり、王朝交替説とは関わりなく継体天皇をもって皇統に変更があったとみなす学者は多い。
sen.e: Many scholars have the opinion in that even if Emperor Keitai was in fact the fifth descendant from Emperor Ojin, in view of the notion of dynasty in European sense, it is really an separate dynasty and independent of the theory on the changes of dynasties there was change in the imperial line from Emperor Keitai.

Many scholars took that even if Emperor Keitai was in fact the fifth descendant from Emperor Ojin, in view of the notion of dynasty in European sense, it was really a separate dynasty and independent of the theory on the changes of dynasties there was change in the imperial line from Emperor Keitai.

Many scholars took that even if Emperor Keitai was in fact the fifth descendant from Emperor Ojin, in view of the notion of dynasty in European sense, it was really a separate dynasty and independent of the theory on the changes of dynasties there was change in the imperial line from Emperor Keitai.

sen.j: ただし、継体天皇の即位に当たっては前政権の支配機構をそっくりそのまま受け継いでいること、また血統の点でも前の大王家の皇女を妻として入り婿の形で皇位を継承していることなどから、これを「王朝」として区別できるかどうか疑問とする考え方もある。
sen.e: However, some scholars think that it is questionable to think that Keitai dynasty as a separate 'dynasty' because at the enthronement of Emperor Keitai he inherited the form of government as it is from the previous government and he inherited the imperial throne as a man who took his wife's premarital family name.

However, some scholars think that it is questionable to think that Keitai dynasty as a separate 'dynasty' because at the enthronement of Emperor Keitai he inherited the form of government as it was from the previous government, and in the blood line, he inherited the imperial throne as a man whose wife was a princess of the previous great kings family and became irimuko (man who takes his wife's premarital family name).

However, some scholars think that it is questionable to think that Keitai dynasty as a separate 'dynasty' because at the enthronement of Emperor Keitai he inherited the form of government as it was from the previous government, and in the blood line, he inherited the imperial throne as a man whose wife was a princess of the previous great kings family and became irimuko (man who takes his wife's premarital family name).

sen.j: 鳥越憲三郎が唱えた説で、三王朝交替説では実在を否定されている神武天皇及びいわゆる欠史八代の天皇は実在した天皇であり、崇神王朝以前に存在した奈良県葛城地方を拠点とした王朝であったが崇神王朝に滅ぼされたとする説。
sen.e: This theory was advocated by Kensaburo TORIGOE; according to this theory, Emperor Jinmu and so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight undocumented Sovereigns) who were denied the existence by the advocates of the changes of the three dynasties existed before the Sujin dynasty; the headquarters of this dynasty was Kazuraki region and was destroyed by the Sujin dynasty.

It was the theory advocated by Kensaburo TORIGOE that Emperor Jinmu and so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight undocumented Sovereigns), who were denied the existence in the changes of the three dynasties theory, were actual persons and they set the base on Katsuragi region in Nara Prefecture before the reign of Emperor Sujin who destroyed the dynasty.

It was the theory advocated by Kensaburo TORIGOE that Emperor Jinmu and so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight undocumented Sovereigns), who were denied the existence in the changes of the three dynasties theory, were actual persons and they set the base on Katsuragi region in Nara Prefecture before the reign of Emperor Sujin who destroyed the dynasty.

sen.j: 詳細は欠史八代実在説からの反論の「葛城王朝説」を参照。
sen.e: Refer to 'The Katsuragi Dynasty Theory' from the argument in the Theory of the Existence of the Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight undocumented sovereigns) for details.
For details, refer to the article of 'The Katsuragi Dynasty Theory' from the argument in the Theory of the Existence of the Kesshi-Hachidai.
For details, refer to the article of 'The Katsuragi Dynasty Theory' from the argument in the Theory of the Existence of the Kesshi-Hachidai.

sen.j: 河内王朝は、瀬戸内海の海上権を握ったことと奈良盆地東南部の有力豪族葛城氏の協力を得たことが強大な河内王朝をつくったと考えられる。
sen.e: It can be thought that Kawachi dynasty made the dynasty strong by holding the maritime power of the Seto Inland Sea and having the cooperation of the Katsuragi clan, an influential local ruling family.

It is thought that strong Kawachi Dynasty were built by holding the maritime power of the Seto Inland Sea and having the cooperation of the Katsuragi clan, an influential local ruling family in the southeast part of Nara basin.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「奈良盆地東南部の」を補足しました。
sen.e: It is thought that strong Kawachi Dynasty were built by holding the maritime power of the Seto Inland Sea and having the cooperation of the Katsuragi clan, an influential local ruling family in the southeast part of Nara basin.

sen.j: 仁徳は葛城襲津彦（そつひこ）の娘盤之媛（いわのひめ）を皇后に立て、のちの履中、反正、允恭などの3天皇を産んでいる。
sen.e: Emperor Nintoku made Iwa no Hime, the daughter of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko his empress, and the Empress bore three Emperors such as Richu, Hanzei, and Ingyo.
Emperor Nintoku married Iwa no Hime, the daughter of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko, as his wife to have three later emperors such as Richu, Hanzei, and Ingyo.
Emperor Nintoku married Iwa no Hime, the daughter of KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko, as his wife to have three later emperors such as Richu, Hanzei, and Ingyo.

sen.j: また、履中は襲津彦の孫黒姫を后とし市辺押盤皇子を産み、その皇子は襲津彦の曾孫に当たる?媛（はえひめ）を后としてのちの顕宗、仁賢の2天皇を産んでいる。
sen.e: Emperor Richu made Kurohime, the grandchild of Sotsuhiko, his empress and the empress bore Ichibe no Oshiwa no Miko; the prince of Ichibe no Oshiwa no Miko made Haehime, the great-grandchild of Sotsuhiko his empress; this empress bore the later two Emperors, Kenzo and Ninken.

Emperor Richu married Kurohime, the grandchild of Sotsuhiko, as his wife to have ICHIBE no Oshiwa no Miko who married Haehime, the great-grandchild of Sotsuhiko, as his wife to have the later two emperors, Kenzo and Ninken.

Emperor Richu married Kurohime, the grandchild of Sotsuhiko, as his wife to have ICHIBE no Oshiwa no Miko who married Haehime, the great-grandchild of Sotsuhiko, as his wife to have the later two emperors, Kenzo and Ninken.

sen.j: さらに、仁徳は葛城円大臣の娘韓姫（からひめ）を后としてのちの清寧天皇を産むという所伝もある。
sen.e: Furthermore, there is a legend in which Emperor Nintoku made Karahime, the daughter of Katsuragi no Tsubura no Omi his Empress and this empress bore later Emperor Seinei.
Furthermore, there is a legend in which Emperor Nintoku married Karahime, the daughter of KATSURAGI no Tsubura no Omi as his wife to have later Emperor Seinei.
Furthermore, there is a legend in which Emperor Nintoku married Karahime, the daughter of KATSURAGI no Tsubura no Omi as his wife to have later Emperor Seinei.

sen.j: こうした『記紀』などの記述から史実かどうかは別にしても葛城氏が河内王朝と密接な関係があったといえる。
sen.e: It can be said that there was a close relationship between Katsuragi clan and Kawachi Dynasty, independent of these descriptions in "Kojiki and Nihon Shoki" are historical facts.
It can be said that there was a close relationship between the Katsuragi clan and Kawachi Dynasty, independent of these descriptions in the "Kojiki" and the "Nihon Shoki" are historical facts.
It can be said that there was a close relationship between the Katsuragi clan and Kawachi Dynasty, independent of these descriptions in the "Kojiki" and the "Nihon Shoki" are historical facts.

tit.e: The Theory of Dynasty by Equestrian People Who Conquered the Preceding Dynasty
Dynasty by the Conquering Horseback Races Theory
Dynasty by the Conquering Horseback Races Theory

sen.j: 江上波夫が唱えた説で、大陸の狩猟騎馬民族が北九州を経由して4世紀末頃大阪平野に上陸し、征服国家を打ち立てたとする。
sen.e: This is the theory advocated by Namio EGAMI; according to this theory, toward the end of the fourth century hunting equestrian people came from the Korean Peninsula to Osaka plain through Kitakyushu and conquered the dynasty existed and established a new dynasty.

This is the theory advocated by Namio EGAMI that in the end of the fourth century, hunting horseback races came from the Continent to Osaka Plain through Northern Kyushu and conquered the dynasty existed to establish a new dynasty.

This is the theory advocated by Namio EGAMI that in the end of the fourth century, hunting horseback races came from the Continent to Osaka Plain through Northern Kyushu and conquered the dynasty existed to establish a new dynasty.

sen.j: 邪馬台国九州説を発展させ、大宰府（太宰府）を首都とする九州王朝が成立したが、663年（天智元年）「白村江の戦い」の敗北をきっかけとしてヤマト王権により滅亡させられたとする古田武彦が唱えた九州王朝説の所論によれば、大化の改新として仮託された事件により後の天智天皇・天武天皇が権力奪取する以前の記紀の神代神話と皇統譜や事跡の記述の多くは九州王朝からの剽窃による創作であり、それまでのヤマト王権は統一王朝ではなかったとする。
sen.e: This theory is based on the Yamataikoku Kyushu Theory and advocated by Takehiko FURUTA; according to Furuta, Yamataikoku was established making Dazaifu as the capital; however this dynasty in Kyushu was overthrown by the Yamato sovereign in 663 and the defeat was triggered by the Battle of Hakusukinoe (Battle of Baekgang); Furuta says that most of the myth in the age of the gods, the genealogy of the Imperial Family, and the achievements by the Imperial Family described in Kojiki and Nihon Shoki before Emperor Tenchi and Emperor Tenmu seized the political power through the incident called Taika Reforms were mostly fiction in which the materials were freely taken from the Kyushu Dynasty; up to the fall of the Kyushu Dynasty the Yamato Sovereignty was not a unified dynasty.

Developing the Yamatai-koku Kingdom in Kyushu, by the Kyushu Dynasty Theory advocated by Takehiko FURUTA that the Kyushu Dynasty was established with the capital Dazaifu but was destroyed by the Yamato Administration triggered by the lost in 'Battle of Hakusukinoe' (Battle of Baekgang) in 663, most of the immemorial myth, the genealogy and the achievements of the Imperial Family in Kojiki and Nihon Shoki before later Emperor Tenchi and Emperor Tenmu seized the political power through the incident called Taika Reforms were fiction by plagiarism from the Kyushu Dynasty and until then, the Yamato Administration was not a unified dynasty.

Developing the Yamatai-koku Kingdom in Kyushu, by the Kyushu Dynasty Theory advocated by Takehiko FURUTA that the Kyushu Dynasty was established with the capital Dazaifu but was destroyed by the Yamato Administration triggered by the lost in 'Battle of Hakusukinoe' (Battle of Baekgang) in 663, most of the immemorial myth, the genealogy and the achievements of the Imperial Family in Kojiki and Nihon Shoki before later Emperor Tenchi and Emperor Tenmu seized the political power through the incident called Taika Reforms were fiction by plagiarism from the Kyushu Dynasty and until then, the Yamato Administration was not a unified dynasty.

sen.j: 両王朝並立をもって古田の「多元的古代史観」という。
sen.e: This juxtaposition of two dynasties is called 'Pluralistic Views of Ancient Japanese History of Furuta.'
The two dynasties existed at the same time is called 'Pluralistic Views of Ancient Japanese History' by Furuta.
The two dynasties existed at the same time is called 'Pluralistic Views of Ancient Japanese History' by Furuta.
